front.title: Transclude Preference for the Prefer Header for HTTP (RFC-7240)

abstract.t: The specification for Transclude preference is an extension to the Prefer Header for HTTP . It works similar to other preferences defined in , such as: return, respond-async, wait and handling.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: "Prefer Header for HTTP" proposes a new HTTP header that is used to indicate that particular server behaviors are preferred by the client but are not required for successful completion of the request. It further defines several standard Preferences, such as "return" preference which lets the server know that the client would prefer specific representation of a resource, e.g. full vs. minimal.

In the age of mobile applications that are very sensitive to network latency and throughput, this allows servers to tune and optimize its response payload based on client preferences, for instance: to only sent a mobile app minimal payload when it doesn't full response.

Closely related to the size of the payload, is the number of HTTP requests a client needs to make to get all of the required data. When server sends hypermedia responses (e.g. in the case of Hypermedia APIs) some of the response data may be referenced via a URI link instead of being embedded in the payload itself. This can cause issues for certain clients, such as mobile applications, if they are forced to make multiple requests to get to the needed data.

Transclude preference notifies the server that the client would prefer the server to proactively transclude certain links (as identified by their link relations) so that once the client receives the resulting payload all of the required content is already embedded in the output.

abstract.t: This specification defines an HTTP header field that can be used by a client to request that certain behaviors be employed by a server while processing a request.
Key words for use in RFCs to Indicate Requirement Levels.
This document specifies relation types for Web links, and defines a registry for them. It also defines the use of such links in HTTP headers with the Link header field.
